Description: Egyptian limestone musician or sphinx figure. Fragment of head, in soft limestone, painted.
Production place: Made in: Egypt, Memphis or Nile Delta
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Antikenmuseum, Heidelberg. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A range of crudely carved limestone animals and fantastic creatures were found at Naukratis. Sphinxes and upright human headed birds/cats and griffins were the most common of these. Some may represent a ‘Libyan’ or ‘Bastet’ sphinx, representing Libyan influence on Egyptian sculpture of the 1st millennium BC (Gubel 1998, 632-645). Relatively common at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1886,0401.1519, GR 1886,0401.1518 and possibly GR 2011,5011.7; Boston MFA 86.394, Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-G.72, AN1886.459, AN1886.458; Brussels Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1852; Heidelberg Archäologisches Institut der Universität ST55). Petrie dated these, with other limestone figures, between the 6th and 4th centuries BC (Petrie 1886, 40, pl.19.1&3), though one was found in a Ptolemaic level (ibid.). Hogarth found one in a ‘5th century BC’ well deposit (Hogarth 1905, 122; Hogarth Diary 24-25/04/1903, well 2 bottom). These are identical style to the ‘concubine’ and drummer figures of the Saite period, also found in the mid 6th century BC levels of the Scarab Factory (Petrie 1886, 40, Level 335). Unprovenanced Late Period parallel (Petrie Museum UC59370). Some of the highly varied deviations from this form, such as lying sphinxes, may be later in date (British Museum 1886,0401.1396 and 1886,0401.1485), as they have Late Period or Ptolemaic parallels from Memphis (Anthes 1959; 1965, see also in terracotta Ashton 2003a, 77, Petrie Museum, UC 48012-6; Nicholson & Thomas 2013, 73, P-390) and Saqqâra (Quibbel 1907, pl.30.6a-c; see also in terracotta Jeffreys et. al. 1988, fig. 64, nos.77/308 and 77/u 209) and unprovenanced (Petrie Museum UC60105, see also in terracotta Török 1995, no. 126; 98-9, pl.65, no. 129). Anthes 1959. Mit Rahineh, 1955. Philadelphia, University Museum, University of Pennsylvania. Anthes 1965. Mit Rahineh, 1956. Philadelphia, University Museum, University of Pennsylvania. Ashton, S. Willems (eds), Egyptian religion: the last thousand years ; studies dedicated to the memory of Jan Quaegebeur. Vol 1 (OLA 84). Leuven : Peeters 629 -645. Jeffreys, D. G., Smith, H. S., Price, M., & Giddy, L. L, 1988. The Anubieion at Saqqâra. Egypt Exploration Society Excavation memoirs 54, London. Martin, G. T. 1981. The sacred animal necropolis at North Saqqâra: the southern dependencies of the main temple complex. Egypt Exploration Society Excavation Memoirs 50, London. Quibell, 1907. Excavations at Saqqara 1905-1906. Le Caire: Imprimerie de l'Institut français d'archéologie orientale. Török, L. 1995, Hellenistic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Roma. Thomas, R. I. & Nicholson, P. T. 2013. Figurines in Nicholson, P. T. (ed.) Working in Memphis: The production of faience at Roman period Kom Helul. London: Egypt Exploration Society: 41-74.
